{{other people|Mike Milligan}} {{Infobox college coach | name = Mike Milligan | image = MikeMilliganPort.jpg | alt = | caption = Milligan during his football head coaching tenure at Pittsburgh | sport = [[American football|Football]], [[basketball]] | birth_date = May 27, 1904{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sdgNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=SGoDAAAAIBAJ&dq=walter%20and%20mike%20and%20milligan&pg=6392%2C6003643 | title=Year-to-Year Pact Unsatisfactory, So Job Is Now Open | last=Sell | first=Jack | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=1950-01-28}} | birth_place = | death_date = May 8th 1978 | death_place = | alma_mater = | player_sport1 = Football | player_years2 = 1929–1931 | player_team2 = [[Pittsburgh Panthers football|Pittsburgh]] | player_positions = [[Guard (American football)|Guard]] | coach_sport1 = Football | coach_years2 = 1934–1938 | coach_team2 = [[Pittsburgh Panthers football|Pittsburgh]] (freshmen) | coach_years3 = 1939–1940 | coach_team3 = [[Florida Gators football|Florida]] (assistant) | coach_years4 = 1941–1945 | coach_team4 = [[Tulsa Golden Hurricane football|Tulsa]] (assistant) | coach_years5 = 1946 | coach_team5 = [[Pittsburgh Panthers football|Pittsburgh]] (line) | coach_years6 = 1947–1949 | coach_team6 = [[Pittsburgh Panthers football|Pittsburgh]] | coach_years7 = 1950 | coach_team7 = [[USC Trojans football|USC]] (assistant) | coach_years8 = 1951–1952 | coach_team8 = [[Purdue Boilermakers football|Purdue]] (assistant) | coach_years9 = 1953–1955 | coach_team9 = [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|Nebraska]] (assistant) | coach_sport10 = Basketball | coach_years11 = 1942–1943 | coach_team11 = [[Tulsa Golden Hurricane men's basketball|Tulsa]] | overall_record = 13–14 (football)
0–10 (basketball) | bowl_record = | tournament_record = | championships = | awards = [[United Press]] "Coach of the Week"{{Cite document | url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=pittyearbooks&cc=pittyearbooks&idno=1950e49702&node=1950e49702%3A2&frm=frameset&view=image&seq=261 | title=The Owl | year=1950 | pages=256 | publisher=University of Pittsburgh | location=Pittsburgh, PA | accessdate=2009-09-14 | postscript=.}}
Aliquippa Sports Hall of Fame{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=l9wNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Am0DAAAAIBAJ&dq=walter%20and%20mike%20and%20milligan&pg=6014%2C1000487 | title=Quip Hall to Induct 6 | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | date=1974-01-10 | location=Pittsburgh, PA | accessdate=2009-09-13}} | coaching_records = }} '''Walter Scott "Mike" Milligan''' (May 27, 1904 – 1978) was an [[American football]] player and coach of football and [[basketball]]. He served as the head football coach at the [[University of Pittsburgh]] from 1947 to 1949 and for one season as the head basketball coach at the [[University of Tulsa]] (1942–43). ==Playing days== Milligan played high school football at [[Aliquippa High School]] and [[The Kiski School|Kiski School]].{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=whENAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PWoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3811,6384058&dq | title=Milligan Accepts Coaching Job with Coast School | first=Jack | last=Sell | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | date=1950-08-30 | location=Pittsburgh, PA | accessdate=2009-09-13}} While at college at the University of Pittsburgh, Milligan played [[Guard (American football)|guard]] from 1929 to 1931 under the school's legendary coach [[Jock Sutherland]]. The lightest of Pitt guards in 1930, and listed at a height of 5 feet, 10 inches and weighing 168 pounds, Milligan broke into the lineup at left guard when Hart Morris was injured in an October 11 game at [[Case Western Reserve University|Western Reserve]].{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cPoMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PmkDAAAAIBAJ&dq=walter%20and%20mike%20and%20milligan&pg=4376%2C6279473 | title=Pitt-Tech Comparisons | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=1930-11-06 | accessdate=2009-09-14}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The teams on which Milligan played while at Pitt were regional powers and nationally regarded. The 1929 Pitt team went undefeated in the regular season and won the Eastern Championship{{cite book | url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=pittathletics;cc=pittathletics;q1=eastern%20titles;rgn=full%20text;idno=1975d004652;didno=1975d004652;view=image;seq=0056 | title=University of Pittsburgh 1975 football media guide | pages=54 | publisher=University of Pittsburgh | year=1975 | accessdate=2008-08-26 | location=Pittsburgh, PA | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110520024453/http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=pittathletics%3Bcc%3Dpittathletics%3Bq1%3Deastern%20titles%3Brgn%3Dfull%20text%3Bidno%3D1975d004652%3Bdidno%3D1975d004652%3Bview%3Dimage%3Bseq%3D0056 | archivedate=2011-05-20 | df= }} and appeared in the [[Rose Bowl Game|Rose Bowl]] losing to [[USC Trojans football|USC]]. The loss did not prevent football historian [[Parke H. Davis]] from naming Pitt as that season's national champion.{{cite web|url=http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_ia/bigeast/pittsburgh/all_national_champs.php |title=Pittsburgh All National Championships: Pittsburgh Total National Championships |publisher=College Football Data Warehouse |accessdate=2009-04-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704202839/http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/div_ia/bigeast/pittsburgh/all_national_champs.php |archivedate=2008-07-04 |df= }} The following season, Milligan's first as a regular starter, saw the Panthers go 6–2–1. This was followed by an 8–1 finish in 1931 in which the Panthers recorded six shutouts, including a 40–0 dismantling of [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|Nebraska]]. That season also saw Pitt defeat [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]] in [[State College, Pennsylvania|State College]], using only one first-string player, by a score of 41–6 en route to winning the Eastern Championship.{{cite book | url = | last = Sciullo Jr. | first = Sam | title = University of Pittsburgh Football Vault: The History of the Panthers | pages = 47 | year = 2008 | isbn = 0-7948-2653-9 | publisher = Whitman Publishing, LLC | location=Atlanta, GA }} These accomplishments would prompt Parke Davis to again name the Panthers national champions. During his summers in college, Milligan worked as a desk sergeant with the [[Aliquippa, Pennsylvania|Aliquippa]] Police Department.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=2HY9Fer-FE0C&lpg=PP1&dq=tales%20from%20the%20pitt%20panthers&pg=PA10#v=onepage&q= | title=Tales from the Pitt Panthers | last=Sciullo Jr. | first=Sam | year=2004 | publisher=Sports Publishing L.L.C. | location=Champaign, IL | pages=9–10 | isbn=1-58261-198-X | accessdate=2009-09-13}} ==Coaching career== As a coach, Milligan held several assistant football coaching positions during his career, in which he typically specialized in coaching the [[Lineman (American football)|lines]]. He had his only tenure as a head football coach for three seasons at his [[alma mater]], the University of Pittsburgh. Milligan served one season as the head coach for the basketball team at Tulsa, where he also served as a football assistant. ===Early years=== Milligan became an assistant coach at Pitt under head coach Jock Sutherland in 1934. He remained a coach at the university, where he served as the coach of the football program's freshman squad,{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ozMOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4X0DAAAAIBAJ&dq=mike%20milligan&pg=2572%2C4405940 | title=Alec Fox, Eddie Schultz Added To Panthers' Gridiron Staff | last=Sell | first=Jack | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | date=1937-03-23 | accessdate=2009-09-14}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} until he quit shortly after the resignation of Sutherland in 1938. From there Milligan took an assistant coaching position at [[Florida Gators football|Florida]] which was followed by an assistant position at [[Tulsa Golden Hurricane football|Tulsa]] where he served as the offensive line coach.{{cite news| title=Southern California's Stock Rises With Return Of Several Injured Players | newspaper=''[[Hartford Courant]]'' | date=1944-12-27}} ===Tulsa basketball head coach=== While at Tulsa, Milligan took over head [[Tulsa Golden Hurricane men's basketball|basketball]] coaching duties from [[Tex Ryon]] who left in 1942 after his second stint coaching the team. Milligan was winless in his basketball coaching tenure at Tulsa, where he went 0–10 during the 1942-43 season. Milligan was replaced as the Tulsa's basketball coach the following year by [[Woody West]].Bonham, Chad. ''Golden Hurricane Basketball at the University of Tulsa.'' Chicago: Arcadia, 2004, pg. 19 ===Pitt football head coach=== {{Quote box | quote ="[Milligan] is, in my lifetime, the least appreciated Pitt football coach." | source =Alex Kramer, Pitt football historian | width =350px | align =right }} [[File:MikeMilliganatPitt.jpg|thumb|right|Pitt football head coach "Mike" Milligan (right) congratulates [[Nick Bolkovac]] after a 7-0 shut out of undefeated Penn State on November 20, 1948. In the fourth quarter, Bolkovac scored the winning touchdown when he intercepted a pass and returned it from the 23 yard line. Bolkovac also prevented a tying score on the last play of the game by stopping Penn State [[Fullback (American football)|fullback]] [[Fran Rogel]] at the Pitt one yard line.{{Cite document | url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=pittyearbooks&cc=pittyearbooks&xc=1&idno=1949e49702&g=documentingpitt&xg=1&q1=Milligan&frm=frameset&view=image&seq=258 | title=The Owl | year=1949 | pages=253 | publisher=University of Pittsburgh | location=Pittsburgh, PA | accessdate=2009-09-14 | postscript=.}}]] Milligan returned to his alma mater in 1946 as a top assistant for Pitt under head coach [[Wes Fesler]], who left after his only season at Pitt to coach his alma mater [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State]]. Fesler's departure opened the door for Milligan's promotion to the head coaching position. Milligan's head coaching tenure at Pitt was underscored by one of the most satisfying wins in Pitt history when the Panthers defeated the Fesler-coached Ohio State team 12–0 for their only win of the 1947 season. Milligan brought Pitt back to winning records in 1948 and 1949, achieving consecutive 6–3 seasons that included appearances in the national rankings and back-to-back shutouts of [[Penn State Nittany Lions football|Penn State]], the first of which snapped Penn State's 17-game unbeaten streak. After Pitt, a twenty-point underdog,{{Cite document | url=http://digital.library.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/t/text/pageviewer-idx?c=pittyearbooks&cc=pittyearbooks&idno=1950e49702&node=1950e49702%3A2&frm=frameset&view=image&seq=265 | title=The Owl | year=1950 | pages=260 | publisher=University of Pittsburgh | location=Pittsburgh, PA | accessdate=2009-09-14 | postscript=.}} defeated defending [[1949 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl]] champion [[Northwestern Wildcats football|Northwestern]] on the road on October 1, 1949, Milligan was named the [[United Press]] "Coach of the Week". At the end of the 1949 season, he was also nominated for the [[Scripps-Howard]] "Coach of the Year" award. However, Milligan resigned on January 27, 1950,{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NEYNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=n2oDAAAAIBAJ&dq=walter%20and%20mike%20and%20milligan&pg=3760%2C2272795 | title=A Story of Three Coaches | last=Sell | first=Jack | newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette | location=Pittsburgh, PA | date=1953-10-08 | accessdate=2009-09-14}} due to a perceived snub by the university offering him only a one-year contract, and he never returned to a head coaching position. ===Later years=== Following his stint as the Pitt head coach, Milligan took a series of assistant football coaching positions and was a highly regarded as a line coach. He spent a year as an assistant at [[USC Trojans football|USC]] in 1950, was an assistant at [[Purdue Boilermakers football|Purdue]] from 1951 to 1952, and then moved to an assistant position at [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|Nebraska]] beginning from 1953 to 1955.{{cite web | url=http://www.huskers.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=100&ATCLID=43 | title=Assistant Football Coaches at Nebraska - 1926 to Present | publisher=Huskers.com - Nebraska Athletics Official Web Site | accessdate=2009-09-14}} ==Head coaching record== ===Football=== {{CFB Yearly Record Start | type = coach | team = |
